article.title: Pulsar Wind Nebulae Created by Fast-Moving Pulsars

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the distributions of spin-down power (E-dot) and characteristic age for pulsars associated with SPWNe. What can be inferred about the majority of pulsars powering SPWNe?
choices: They are very young pulsars with ages less than 10,000 years.
They are mostly middle-aged or old pulsars with a wide range of spin-down powers.
They are all located within their parent supernova remnants.
They are all extremely powerful pulsars with E-dot greater than 10^37 erg/s.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure presents a collection of Chandra ACIS images showcasing 18 different SPWNe. What common feature can be observed in most of these images, highlighting the effect of supersonic pulsar motion?
choices: Perfectly spherical PWN bubbles surrounding the pulsars.
Extended, often elongated, structures trailing behind the pulsars.
Bright, compact nebulae without any diffuse emission.
Clear evidence of interaction with the reverse shocks of supernova remnants.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure presents Chandra ACIS images of PWNe where axial outflows dominate over equatorial components. Based on the observed morphologies, what can be inferred about the pulsar wind geometry in these systems?
choices: The pulsar wind is isotropic, with equal energy flow in all directions.
The pulsar wind is primarily concentrated in the equatorial plane.
The pulsar wind is predominantly channeled along the pulsar spin axis.
The observed structures are not related to the pulsar wind geometry but rather interactions with the surrounding medium.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares PWN morphologies and pulsar light curves for three different pulsars. The similar light curves suggest similar viewing geometries. What can be inferred about the relationship between PWN head morphology and pulsar wind geometry based on this comparison?
choices: There is no clear connection between PWN head morphology and pulsar wind geometry.
PWNe with similar light curves always have identical head morphologies.
The observed differences in PWN head morphologies could be attributed to differing viewing geometries despite similar pulsar wind geometries.
PWN head morphology is entirely determined by the properties of the surrounding medium and is independent of the pulsar wind geometry.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure displays extended tails behind four pulsars observed in X-rays and radio. What crucial information can be obtained from the morphology of these tails, particularly in the context of studying supernova explosion models?
choices: The age of the pulsar.
The spin period of the pulsar.
The projected velocity of the pulsar.
The magnetic field strength of the pulsar.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows Chandra images of SPWNe that likely move with mildly supersonic velocities. What is the dominant mechanism shaping the observed jet-like structures in these PWNe?
choices: The intrinsic collimated nature of the pulsar wind.
The ram pressure from the supersonic motion of the pulsar through the ISM.
Interaction with the reverse shock of the parent supernova remnant.
Magnetic confinement by the surrounding ISM magnetic field.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure presents radio images of various pulsar tails. What is the main characteristic of the G327.1-1.1 (Snail) PWN that distinguishes it from other PWNe shown in this figure?
choices: Its radio tail displays a clear increase in brightness with distance from the pulsar.
Its radio tail shows a continuous decrease in brightness with distance from the pulsar.
Its radio tail maintains a nearly constant brightness over its length before connecting to a spherical structure.
Its radio tail exhibits a series of bright, expanding "bubbles" along its length.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure illustrates the variation of spectral slopes along the tails of four different pulsars. What can explain the lack of significant spectral softening (cooling) observed in the tails of B0355+54 and J1509-5850 compared to the Mouse and Lighthouse PWNe?
choices: Lower magnetic fields in the tails of B0355+54 and J1509-5850, leading to less efficient synchrotron cooling.
Continuous particle re-acceleration occurring in the tails of B0355+54 and J1509-5850, counteracting the cooling process.
A higher concentration of dust and gas in the tails of the Mouse and Lighthouse PWNe, leading to enhanced cooling.
The presence of strong shocks in the tails of the Mouse and Lighthouse PWNe, resulting in rapid cooling of the particles.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure highlights a perplexing feature observed in some supersonic PWNe: misaligned outflows. What is particularly puzzling about these features in the context of supersonic pulsar motion?
choices: They are much brighter than the pulsar tails.
They appear to be aligned with the pulsar velocity vector.
They originate far away from the pulsar.
They are not confined within the ram-pressure dominated tails.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure presents multi-wavelength observations of PSR J0437-4715, showcasing its Hα bow shock and surrounding emission. What makes this particular system valuable for studying the properties of pulsar bow shocks and PWNe?
choices: It is the only known pulsar with a detected Hα bow shock.
It is the only known pulsar with a detected FUV bow shock.
Its proximity to Earth allows for detailed observations on smaller spatial scales compared to more distant PWNe.
It is the only pulsar for which both the forward shock and the termination shock have been directly imaged.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure displays multi-wavelength observations of the PSR J2124-3358 vicinity, including its FUV and Hα bow shock and its associated X-ray PWN. What makes the morphology of this X-ray PWN unusual compared to other supersonic PWNe?
choices: It exhibits a long, bright tail extending behind the pulsar.
It shows clear evidence of interaction with the reverse shock of the parent supernova remnant.
It is a one-sided, narrow structure confined to a region ahead of the moving pulsar.
It displays a bright, compact head with two symmetric lateral tails.
